article.headline: Montana 67, Montana State 58
article.story: MISSOULA, Mont. (AP) -- The Montana men's basketball team has put together four straight wins after a string of six consecutive losses, with just three games left in Big Sky Conference play. "We're coming together at a strange time and place," Montana coach Pat Kennedy said Saturday, after his team's 67-58 victory over Montana State. "I thought this would be a good test to see how far we've really come." Kamarr Davis scored nine of his 23 points in a key second-half run to lead Montana (9-16 overall, 5-7 league). Calvin Ento, who led Montana State (13-12, 5-7) with a career-high 30 points, tied the score for the ninth time at 46-all on a jumper with 11:42 remaining. "I was just trying to play hard," said Ento, who also had eight rebounds. UM took control with a 16-4 run. During that run, Davis had a three-point play, an assist, hit four free throws and added a jump shot before Kevin Criswell drove the lane for a layup to give Montana a 62-50 lead with 5:24 remaining. "What's been kind of nice, since we went to a three-guard rotation and added the full-court pressure, is that everyone has accepted their role well," Kennedy said. A dunk by Ento, on an assist by Frank Brown, pulled MSU within 62-52 with 4:27 to play, but the Bobcats struggled both from the field and the free throw line and the Grizzlies slowed down their offense to hold on for the win. Ryan Pederson hit a key 3-pointer that gave Montana a 67-52 lead with 2:32 remaining. Criswell's tough defense held Jason Erickson, MSU's leading scorer, to just six points -- 12 below his season average. Erickson made just 1-of-9 shots from the field. "I just wanted to come in a frustrate Jason as much as I could," Criswell said. "He's such a good offensive player. The main factor is I didn't let him touch the ball. If he doesn't touch the ball, he can't do anything." The game was close throughout the first half. Montana held a 26-22 lead on a 3-pointer by Davis before Ento scored five points in MSU's 9-0 run to give the Bobcats a 31-26 lead with 1:46 left in the half. Roy Booker scored six points as Montana closed the half with an 8-0 run to take a 34-31 lead on a tip-in by Matt Dlouhy at the buzzer. "We had a bad stretch at the end of the first half," said MSU coach Mick Durham. Criswell added 12 points for Montana while Booker finished with 11 for Montana, which has won its last three Big Sky games. "The coaches told us, `Don't worry about the record," Criswell said. "After the Eastern loss, we decided we've just got to come in, work hard at practice and if we do that, good things will come."
